Eisenhower Discusses
School's Future Plans

Singleton Named Head
Of Humanities Center
By GREG ALTSHUH
Dr. Charles S. Singleton, professor of
humanistic studies and eminent Dante
scholar, has been appointed director of
the new Humanities Center at Hopkins.
Originally concerned with postdoctoral
studies, the Center has been expanded
to deal with interdisciplinary programs
in the humanities at predoctoral and
Undergraduate levels as well.
The Center is a major part of the
expanded program in the Humanities
for which the University has been attempting to raise $4.5 million.
Dr. Singleton is a Presidential appointee. He will be part of the University administrative staff and will have
some budgetary responsibilities.
At the postdoctoral level, ten to twenty outstanding young scholars each year
will be invited as fellows of the Center.
They will not be attached to any one
department, but will instead work with
faculty and graduate students who have
common interests, irrespective of departmental lines. They will spend approximately a year in residence and will
be given freedom to pursue any personal
scholarly goals.
Dean G. Heberton Evans recently an-

nounced that thanks to the Fels Foundation there is already one postdoctoral
fellow in the field of English, and another in Philosophy has been acquired
for 1966-67.
At the predoctoral level, the language and literature departments are
working out programs which will enable
bright graduate students to earn the
Ph.D. in three years.
For undergrads, new ways are being
sought to bring the student to advanced -level studies. In the English
Department plan, for example, qualified
seniors will be permitted to participate
in one of the seminars being established
for first year grad students.
Literary Interpretation
The new Center is also giving more
attention to theories and methods of
literary interpretation. Recent developments in such fields as linguistics.
anthropology, psychoanalysis and philosophy are being assessed for their. importance to the interpretation of literature.
An international symposium on "Critical Languages and Science of Man" will
be held in October, supported by a grant
of $36,000 from the Ford Foundation.

In his summary, attorney for

that if the police had asked the
defendents to leave, there would

However, Weisgel pointed out,
there was no proof that the
police did ask the demonstrators
to leave, and therefore a decision
of guilty would be ill-conceive
d.
Judge Lamdin, however, did
hand down the maximum sentence. Weisgal immediately filed a habeas corpus appea
l
which was approved.
The defendents were freed in
the custody of Weisgal until
the appelate hearing, scheduled
for sometime in early May.

Budge. Judge!
For an old Hopkin, Judge I. Sewell Lamdin seems
to have it in for his Alma Mater. When the time comes
for that great Alumni Roll Call in the sky, we predict
the good Judge will turn out the pockets of his fraying
robes anti plead poverty. When one begins to speculate
on what the "1" stands for, the first thing that comes to
mind is injustice.
It is a very poor judge indeed who makes a judicial
decision based on extra-judicial concerns. In a recent
trial of the six Hopkins SIDS members arrested in an
anti-war demonstration, Judge Lamdin ruled that they
were to be convicted on charges of disorderly conduct.
Disorderly conduct is defined in terms of obeying
or not obeying a police order. At the time of the arrest
the demonstrators were sitting on the sidewalk and it
was never determined whether the students had been
askd to leave. Instead of searching for a sound basis for
decision Judge Lamdin sought refuge in statements like
"You know nothing of war, all you have are misconceptions". He clearly allowed personal political conviction
to interfere with his judgement of the case.
In convicting a Hopkins student of a disorderly
conduct charge involving a parking violation some weeks
ago (a decision that was later reversed) Lamdin said,
"I don't know what's going on at Hopkins these days.
When I was up there, we never would have thought of
calling a policeman an idiot; I just won't stand for it."
For the Judge's benefit, here is what is happening
at Hopkins: While most of us would not think of calling a policeman an idiot (which, incidentally the student
in question never di(1), many of us are prepared to go
you one better anti refer to a certain judicial bench
warmer in the same terms.
Unfortunately, the conduct of some of the SDS
members did not enhance the strength of their case.
Judge Lamdin rightly convicted an SDS member for
scribbling obscenities on the wall of the Northern District Police Station. Such conduct is immature and not
in keeping with the sincere moral anti political convictions that motivated the protest.
Such a universal loss of dignity and sensibility in a
case of this kind is unfortunate, as the issues are quite
serious. While it would be libelous _to dismiss the whole
bunch, Judge and scribblers, as bastards, all you really
have are misconceptions.

End Is Near
By DAVID ABRAHAMSON
Sex, it seems, is pervading the
entire American scene. For a
short time though, much to the
consolation of the more staid
members of our society, this
creeping dragon was confined to
the regions of advertising and
bathing suits.
A minor uproar was caused
when the trend started to move
toward everyday apparel such as
No-Bra Bra and the No-Girdle
Girdle. But even these shifts
were not all that noticeable.
Aside from a few beach arrests
and a little high blood-pressure,
most of this was taken in stride.
To prove their point, an exhibitionist by the name of Ginsburg was hung up in the halls
of the Supreme Court of the
United States. It would be a
little harder for our children to
get horny mags.
The battle, if not won, had at
least been drawn to a stalemate
on that front. The powers that
be could sleep at night and rest
assured that their little world
would be there in the morning.

Lacrosse In Second Week

The only other front was as
secure as it had been for many,
many years. Figures of public
prominence were absolutely untouchable. Presidents were rarely shown with cigarette in hand
and the fact that a given Chief
Executive might have an afterdinner drink was really a choice
tid-bit of news. Sex, as such,
or even the most indirect reference was totally taboo.
But alas, all that has changed.
Last weekend, two enterprising
reporters of the Argentine magazine Gente collected the sex
scoop of the year. Breaking away
from the pack, they daringly
defied two dozen guards and got
a series of photographs (which
were printed in an issue that had
record sales) of a noteable Unsuspectingly
behind a bush,
changing from her swimming
suit to a pancho.
But then again, a rear end
view of Jackie Kennedy does
leave a lot to be desired.

Romp Over Pump Pops Pole Record

By GARY SMITH

By JOSH TREEM
team
tennis
varsity
The
trounced Western Maryland, 81, Tuesday for its first win of
the season 'after several rainouts and defeats.
Played under overcast skies
and with the temperature in the
forties, Hopkins dropped only
two sets during the match and
atoned for erratic play that had
marked their early season play.
The Jays swept the singles 5-1.
Joe Sorrow, first singles led the
attack by sweeping past Dave
Christhilf 6-1, 6-3. Third singles
Tom Clash, lost only five games
while trimming Frank Bowe
6-1, 6-4.
Mark Ellenbogen, Ken Larsen,
and Barry Butler had only
slightly more trouble in dumping
in
again
opponents
their
straight sets 7-5, 6-4; 6-4, 9-7;
6-1, 9-7; in fourth, fifth and
-sixth singles respectively. Only
Terror Darrell Linton was able
to prevent a Hopkins shutout by
ousting Bob Childers 7-5, 6-3 in
second singles.
Doubles won
The Jays encountered only
minor resistance in rocketing
through the doubles contests
three-love. Sorrow and Childers
combined to dump Christhilf
and Bowe 4 and 2, while second
doubles, Clash and Larsen slammed past Linton and Winterling
2 and 3. The Ellenbogen-Butler
duo ended the scoring and lost
only three games in a 6-0, 6-3
victory.
Coach Tom McDermott was
quite pleased with the team's
showing and the way they rebounded after being shutout, 9-0
by Swarthmore, /the defending
MAC champs. He cited Larsen
and Butler, both of whom won
their first matches of the season.
Hesitant to make a prediction
as to the possibility of a league
championship, McDermott did
state that the key to the season
would lie in the outcome of the
two matches with Loyola.

Hopkins sophomore Bill Pump
broke a 44 year old pole vault
record last Saturday, but the
Blue Jays varsity track team
still suffered a 69-62 defeat at
the hands of Lebanon Valley.
Pump broke the old record of
11' 11%" set in 1922 by E. Arronson, with a leap of 12' 3/2".
In spite of this, Pump did not
even win the event; Horst of
Lebanon Valley vaulted 13' 1/4,'•
Pump has been using the fiberglass pole.

Walker Wins
Bo Walker again led Hopkins
with wins in both the high and
low hurdles, with times of 16.7
and 27.6 respectively. He also
notched a second in the long
jump and a third in the discus.
Other victories for Hopkins
were notched by Kevin Murphy
in the two mile in a time of
10:16.4, George Costello in the
440 with a time of 54.3, Dave
Strobel in the shot put in 41' 8",

and Pete Rowny in the high
jump with a leap of 5'8".
Lack Depth
While Coach Polonowski was
relatively pleased by the team's
performance, he felt the team's
lack of depth, especially in the
sprints, Contributed to the Jay's
defeat.This defeat leaves Hopkins
with a 1-2 record on the season,

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 22, 1966

Baseballers'Fortunes Slip, Ten, Over .500,
Out to HaltSlide Vs.Bears Waits For Army
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Iinmersed in one of its all-toocustomary season-long slides, the
varsity baseball team will attempt to stave off further adversity tomorrow at 2:00 P.M. when
it hosts Ursinu.s.
Coach Gary Barrette, unwilling to comment very much about
his group's fortunes this spring,
did name soph Eric Javel to start
on the mound Saturday, with
Jim Elder ready to step in.
Poor Statistics
The varsity mentor's reluctance to opine about the .squad's
troubles is quite understandable,
since the team statistics paint a
most vivid picture of what's happening. A few of the most revealing (as of Monday) are as
follows: team batting average:
Hopkins .177, Opponents .244;
runs: Hopkins 11, Opponents 52;
errors: Hopkins 27, Opponents
12: and fielding average: Hopkin.s .872. Opponents .941.
As a result of the above displayed glove deficencies, thirtyone of the team's fifty-two runs
allowed thus far have been un-

earned, a factor which makes
the earned run averages (again
as of Monday) of Jim Elder
(2.25), Javel (3.50), Ted Ruggemer (4.50), Bob Snyder (6.75),
and Amy Michelson (7.42) appear reasonably presentable.
Repeat Defeat
Recent action saw the nine fall
to P.M.C., Swarthmore, and
Western Maryland by counts of

6-0, 13-3, and 13-0. The most
notable individual performance
in this trio of contests was probably Elder's eight inning, six
strikeout job against P.M.C.
Outfielder Ray Wier, making
his first appearance of the year
in the P.M.C. fray, reinjured his
leg and is lost to the Jays for an
indefinite period.

Frosh Sports

'Crossers Annex Two Wins
Still coming on strong, the
freshman lacrosse team downed
Severn 10-5 last Tuesday afternoon.
Charlie Goodell, Will Scroggs,
Phil Buck, and Mike Clark were
all cited for their outstanding
jobs. Goodell had four goals,
Buck three and two assists, Jim
Feely two and one assist, and
John Gorczyk had one goal.
John Kelly, again, put on a
strong showing in the goal.
Dumped Bainbridge
After a 9-3 win over Friend's,
the Baby Jays smashed a supposedly tough team from Bainbridge 15-6. Bob Comisky looked
real fine on attack in that
scrambler. The defense of Clark,
Joe Cardillo, and Bob Crutchley
has been outstanding in every
game so far this season, and
this was more than true in the
Bainbridge game.
With the Severn stickmen
having already defeated the
Navy Plebes this year and then
losing to Friends, it may be time
for the Baby Jays "Navy Psych."

The two toughest games of the
season are yet to be played, Navy
and then the Maryland frosh.
The next game will be against
St. Paul's on Friday, April 29, on
Homewood field at 3:30 P.M.
The frosh track team, continuing what looks to be a winning season, captured its second
victory by defeating Forest Park,
66-56.
The Jays opened their season
with an impressive 91-54 victory
over Mount St. Joseph's even
though they were a little out of
condition from spring vacation.
They succeeded in capturing the
first place honors over the unprepared Gaels in every running
event and scoring in all field
events.
Several Winners
Hurdler Wade Wright led the
frosh leggers, winning the high
and low hurdles and running a
leg on the mile relay. Bob Rudenstein captured first places in
both dashes against the Gaels.
In the middle distance races,
Ralph Hingson and Paul Carlson

finished one-two in the quarter,
and John Gardiner won the 880
yard run, with Bob Guza taking
second place.
Second Victory
Last Tuesday in the meet
against Forest Park, the frosh
redeemed a very disheartening
trouncing which they received
from the Woodsmen last year.
The capture of several second
and third places indicated that
(Continued on Page 6)

By JOHN M. BRICKMAN
The varsity lacrosse team takes
advantage of a gap in its schedule, using a week's layoff to prepare for next Saturday's invasion
of an as-yet undefeated Army
team. The Jays ran off their
third and fourth straight victories the past week, and went
over the .500 mark for the first
time this season, as they whipped
Virginia 10-1 on Saturday and
topped Rutgers 8-7 on Wednesday.
At Chalottesville, the team held
Virginia scoreless for three and
a half periods. Phil Kneip, now
playing crease attack, scored
three goals and one assist, and
Downy McCarty notched a goal
and four assists. Jerome Schnydman and Wayne Towns each
contributed two scores.
Against Rutgers, the game was
considerably closer. Down 2-1,
the Jays pulled to a 5-3 halftime
edge, then saw Rutgers tie the
count at 6-6. Then Mike Oidick,
who had three for the day,
scored after coming up with a
rebound behind, and Schnydman
—who was tremendous all day
on faceoffs and gmunders (171—
hit what proved to be the winning goal after putting a variety
of moves on Rutgers goalie Eddie
Schaivitz.
Rutgers came back to make
the score 8-7, and actually had
possession in the offensive zone
with some 15 seconds to play.

After a time out, Coach Bob
Naso tried to get tricky by not
giving the ball to star attackman Paul Popsont--who had been
tied up the whole afternoon by
Hank Kaestner—but to soph
Paul Joinnidis, who already had
three on the day. But Jay Coach
Bob Scott countered with a neat
move, putting Kaestner on the
man with ball. Hank responded
by checking the ball loose and
kicking it far upfield, insuring
the Jay victory.
Scott now looks forward to the
Army game, here before a Big
Weekend crowd next Saturday.
The West Pointers have already
registered a 10-6 win over Rutgers and a 12-7 victory over
Princeton—the latter the same
score by which powerful Maryland defeated the Tigers.

Eisenhower Discusses
School's Future Plans

Singleton Named Head
Of Humanities Center
By GREG ALTSHUH
Dr. Charles S. Singleton, professor of
humanistic studies and eminent Dante
scholar, has been appointed director of
the new Humanities Center at Hopkins.
Originally concerned with postdoctoral
studies, the Center has been expanded
to deal with interdisciplinary programs
in the humanities at predoctoral and
Undergraduate levels as well.
The Center is a major part of the
expanded program in the Humanities
for which the University has been attempting to raise $4.5 million.
Dr. Singleton is a Presidential appointee. He will be part of the University administrative staff and will have
some budgetary responsibilities.
At the postdoctoral level, ten to twenty outstanding young scholars each year
will be invited as fellows of the Center.
They will not be attached to any one
department, but will instead work with
faculty and graduate students who have
common interests, irrespective of departmental lines. They will spend approximately a year in residence and will
be given freedom to pursue any personal
scholarly goals.
Dean G. Heberton Evans recently an-

nounced that thanks to the Fels Foundation there is already one postdoctoral
fellow in the field of English, and another in Philosophy has been acquired
for 1966-67.
At the predoctoral level, the language and literature departments are
working out programs which will enable
bright graduate students to earn the
Ph.D. in three years.
For undergrads, new ways are being
sought to bring the student to advanced -level studies. In the English
Department plan, for example, qualified
seniors will be permitted to participate
in one of the seminars being established
for first year grad students.
Literary Interpretation
The new Center is also giving more
attention to theories and methods of
literary interpretation. Recent developments in such fields as linguistics.
anthropology, psychoanalysis and philosophy are being assessed for their. importance to the interpretation of literature.
An international symposium on "Critical Languages and Science of Man" will
be held in October, supported by a grant
of $36,000 from the Ford Foundation.

Budge. Judge!
For an old Hopkin, Judge I. Sewell Lamdin seems
to have it in for his Alma Mater. When the time comes
for that great Alumni Roll Call in the sky, we predict
the good Judge will turn out the pockets of his fraying
robes anti plead poverty. When one begins to speculate
on what the "1" stands for, the first thing that comes to
mind is injustice.
It is a very poor judge indeed who makes a judicial
decision based on extra-judicial concerns. In a recent
trial of the six Hopkins SIDS members arrested in an
anti-war demonstration, Judge Lamdin ruled that they
were to be convicted on charges of disorderly conduct.
Disorderly conduct is defined in terms of obeying
or not obeying a police order. At the time of the arrest
the demonstrators were sitting on the sidewalk and it
was never determined whether the students had been
askd to leave. Instead of searching for a sound basis for
decision Judge Lamdin sought refuge in statements like
"You know nothing of war, all you have are misconceptions". He clearly allowed personal political conviction
to interfere with his judgement of the case.
In convicting a Hopkins student of a disorderly
conduct charge involving a parking violation some weeks
ago (a decision that was later reversed) Lamdin said,
"I don't know what's going on at Hopkins these days.
When I was up there, we never would have thought of
calling a policeman an idiot; I just won't stand for it."
For the Judge's benefit, here is what is happening
at Hopkins: While most of us would not think of calling a policeman an idiot (which, incidentally the student
in question never di(1), many of us are prepared to go
you one better anti refer to a certain judicial bench
warmer in the same terms.
Unfortunately, the conduct of some of the SDS
members did not enhance the strength of their case.
Judge Lamdin rightly convicted an SDS member for
scribbling obscenities on the wall of the Northern District Police Station. Such conduct is immature and not
in keeping with the sincere moral anti political convictions that motivated the protest.
Such a universal loss of dignity and sensibility in a
case of this kind is unfortunate, as the issues are quite
serious. While it would be libelous _to dismiss the whole
bunch, Judge and scribblers, as bastards, all you really
have are misconceptions.

Fortune
It means the'difference between going to school and
not going to school. It means the difference between
learning and not learning. It means the difference between a monumental intellectual and social growth for
sonic individual, some person who has the capacity, the
incentive, the moral right to seek knowledge, and the
loss of that monumental growth. To the average Hoppie
it means the difference between seeing a flick and missing it, and yet by Wednesday of this week only ninehundred tickets to "The Boys From Syracuse" had been
sold. Nine-hundred out of a possible twenty five hundred.
A veritable army of people have given hours of
their time and effort to make "Syracuse" a dramatic
and financial success. People from other institutions
have offered their labor. Faculty members have bought
large blocks of seats for the underprivileged. Where is
the needed support from the Ilopkins undergraduate
and graduate communities. There but for fortune. .

End Is Near
By DAVID ABRAHAMSON
Sex, it seems, is pervading the
entire American scene. For a
short time though, much to the
consolation of the more staid
members of our society, this
creeping dragon was confined to
the regions of advertising and
bathing suits.
A minor uproar was caused
when the trend started to move
toward everyday apparel such as
No-Bra Bra and the No-Girdle
Girdle. But even these shifts
were not all that noticeable.
Aside from a few beach arrests
and a little high blood-pressure,
most of this was taken in stride.
To prove their point, an exhibitionist by the name of Ginsburg was hung up in the halls
of the Supreme Court of the
United States. It would be a
little harder for our children to
get horny mags.
The battle, if not won, had at
least been drawn to a stalemate
on that front. The powers that
be could sleep at night and rest
assured that their little world
would be there in the morning.

Lacrosse In Second Week

The only other front was as
secure as it had been for many,
many years. Figures of public
prominence were absolutely untouchable. Presidents were rarely shown with cigarette in hand
and the fact that a given Chief
Executive might have an afterdinner drink was really a choice
tid-bit of news. Sex, as such,
or even the most indirect reference was totally taboo.
But alas, all that has changed.
Last weekend, two enterprising
reporters of the Argentine magazine Gente collected the sex
scoop of the year. Breaking away
from the pack, they daringly
defied two dozen guards and got
a series of photographs (which
were printed in an issue that had
record sales) of a noteable Unsuspectingly
behind a bush,
changing from her swimming
suit to a pancho.
But then again, a rear end
view of Jackie Kennedy does
leave a lot to be desired.

—not even Mervis Trunz—especially not today with the

Personna is available both in Double Edge style and injector style.

Racketmen Varsity Track
Romp Over Pump Pops Pole Record
Terrors
By GARY SMITH

By JOSH TREEM
team
tennis
varsity
The
trounced Western Maryland, 81, Tuesday for its first win of
the season 'after several rainouts and defeats.
Played under overcast skies
and with the temperature in the
forties, Hopkins dropped only
two sets during the match and
atoned for erratic play that had
marked their early season play.
The Jays swept the singles 5-1.
Joe Sorrow, first singles led the
attack by sweeping past Dave
Christhilf 6-1, 6-3. Third singles
Tom Clash, lost only five games
while trimming Frank Bowe
6-1, 6-4.
Mark Ellenbogen, Ken Larsen,
and Barry Butler had only
slightly more trouble in dumping
in
again
opponents
their
straight sets 7-5, 6-4; 6-4, 9-7;
6-1, 9-7; in fourth, fifth and
-sixth singles respectively. Only
Terror Darrell Linton was able
to prevent a Hopkins shutout by
ousting Bob Childers 7-5, 6-3 in
second singles.
Doubles won
The Jays encountered only
minor resistance in rocketing
through the doubles contests
three-love. Sorrow and Childers
combined to dump Christhilf
and Bowe 4 and 2, while second
doubles, Clash and Larsen slammed past Linton and Winterling
2 and 3. The Ellenbogen-Butler
duo ended the scoring and lost
only three games in a 6-0, 6-3
victory.
Coach Tom McDermott was
quite pleased with the team's
showing and the way they rebounded after being shutout, 9-0
by Swarthmore, /the defending
MAC champs. He cited Larsen
and Butler, both of whom won
their first matches of the season.
Hesitant to make a prediction
as to the possibility of a league
championship, McDermott did
state that the key to the season
would lie in the outcome of the
two matches with Loyola.

Hopkins sophomore Bill Pump
broke a 44 year old pole vault
record last Saturday, but the
Blue Jays varsity track team
still suffered a 69-62 defeat at
the hands of Lebanon Valley.
Pump broke the old record of
11' 11%" set in 1922 by E. Arronson, with a leap of 12' 3/2".
In spite of this, Pump did not
even win the event; Horst of
Lebanon Valley vaulted 13' 1/4,'•
Pump has been using the fiberglass pole.

Walker Wins
Bo Walker again led Hopkins
with wins in both the high and
low hurdles, with times of 16.7
and 27.6 respectively. He also
notched a second in the long
jump and a third in the discus.
Other victories for Hopkins
were notched by Kevin Murphy
in the two mile in a time of
10:16.4, George Costello in the
440 with a time of 54.3, Dave
Strobel in the shot put in 41' 8",

and Pete Rowny in the high
jump with a leap of 5'8".
Lack Depth
While Coach Polonowski was
relatively pleased by the team's
performance, he felt the team's
lack of depth, especially in the
sprints, Contributed to the Jay's
defeat.This defeat leaves Hopkins
with a 1-2 record on the season,
with a triangular meet against
Ursinus and Dickinson scheduled
for tomorrow at Dickinson.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 22, 1966

Baseballers'Fortunes Slip, Ten, Over .500,
Out to HaltSlide Vs.Bears Waits For Army
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Iinmersed in one of its all-toocustomary season-long slides, the
varsity baseball team will attempt to stave off further adversity tomorrow at 2:00 P.M. when
it hosts Ursinu.s.
Coach Gary Barrette, unwilling to comment very much about
his group's fortunes this spring,
did name soph Eric Javel to start
on the mound Saturday, with
Jim Elder ready to step in.
Poor Statistics
The varsity mentor's reluctance to opine about the .squad's
troubles is quite understandable,
since the team statistics paint a
most vivid picture of what's happening. A few of the most revealing (as of Monday) are as
follows: team batting average:
Hopkins .177, Opponents .244;
runs: Hopkins 11, Opponents 52;
errors: Hopkins 27, Opponents
12: and fielding average: Hopkin.s .872. Opponents .941.
As a result of the above displayed glove deficencies, thirtyone of the team's fifty-two runs
allowed thus far have been un-

earned, a factor which makes
the earned run averages (again
as of Monday) of Jim Elder
(2.25), Javel (3.50), Ted Ruggemer (4.50), Bob Snyder (6.75),
and Amy Michelson (7.42) appear reasonably presentable.
Repeat Defeat
Recent action saw the nine fall
to P.M.C., Swarthmore, and
Western Maryland by counts of

6-0, 13-3, and 13-0. The most
notable individual performance
in this trio of contests was probably Elder's eight inning, six
strikeout job against P.M.C.
Outfielder Ray Wier, making
his first appearance of the year
in the P.M.C. fray, reinjured his
leg and is lost to the Jays for an
indefinite period.

Frosh Sports

'Crossers Annex Two Wins
Still coming on strong, the
freshman lacrosse team downed
Severn 10-5 last Tuesday afternoon.
Charlie Goodell, Will Scroggs,
Phil Buck, and Mike Clark were
all cited for their outstanding
jobs. Goodell had four goals,
Buck three and two assists, Jim
Feely two and one assist, and
John Gorczyk had one goal.
John Kelly, again, put on a
strong showing in the goal.
Dumped Bainbridge
After a 9-3 win over Friend's,
the Baby Jays smashed a supposedly tough team from Bainbridge 15-6. Bob Comisky looked
real fine on attack in that
scrambler. The defense of Clark,
Joe Cardillo, and Bob Crutchley
has been outstanding in every
game so far this season, and
this was more than true in the
Bainbridge game.
With the Severn stickmen
having already defeated the
Navy Plebes this year and then
losing to Friends, it may be time
for the Baby Jays "Navy Psych."

The two toughest games of the
season are yet to be played, Navy
and then the Maryland frosh.
The next game will be against
St. Paul's on Friday, April 29, on
Homewood field at 3:30 P.M.
The frosh track team, continuing what looks to be a winning season, captured its second
victory by defeating Forest Park,
66-56.
The Jays opened their season
with an impressive 91-54 victory
over Mount St. Joseph's even
though they were a little out of
condition from spring vacation.
They succeeded in capturing the
first place honors over the unprepared Gaels in every running
event and scoring in all field
events.
Several Winners
Hurdler Wade Wright led the
frosh leggers, winning the high
and low hurdles and running a
leg on the mile relay. Bob Rudenstein captured first places in
both dashes against the Gaels.
In the middle distance races,
Ralph Hingson and Paul Carlson

finished one-two in the quarter,
and John Gardiner won the 880
yard run, with Bob Guza taking
second place.
Second Victory
Last Tuesday in the meet
against Forest Park, the frosh
redeemed a very disheartening
trouncing which they received
from the Woodsmen last year.
The capture of several second
and third places indicated that
(Continued on Page 6)

By JOHN M. BRICKMAN
The varsity lacrosse team takes
advantage of a gap in its schedule, using a week's layoff to prepare for next Saturday's invasion
of an as-yet undefeated Army
team. The Jays ran off their
third and fourth straight victories the past week, and went
over the .500 mark for the first
time this season, as they whipped
Virginia 10-1 on Saturday and
topped Rutgers 8-7 on Wednesday.
At Chalottesville, the team held
Virginia scoreless for three and
a half periods. Phil Kneip, now
playing crease attack, scored
three goals and one assist, and
Downy McCarty notched a goal
and four assists. Jerome Schnydman and Wayne Towns each
contributed two scores.
Against Rutgers, the game was
considerably closer. Down 2-1,
the Jays pulled to a 5-3 halftime
edge, then saw Rutgers tie the
count at 6-6. Then Mike Oidick,
who had three for the day,
scored after coming up with a
rebound behind, and Schnydman
—who was tremendous all day
on faceoffs and gmunders (171—
hit what proved to be the winning goal after putting a variety
of moves on Rutgers goalie Eddie
Schaivitz.
Rutgers came back to make
the score 8-7, and actually had
possession in the offensive zone
with some 15 seconds to play.

After a time out, Coach Bob
Naso tried to get tricky by not
giving the ball to star attackman Paul Popsont--who had been
tied up the whole afternoon by
Hank Kaestner—but to soph
Paul Joinnidis, who already had
three on the day. But Jay Coach
Bob Scott countered with a neat
move, putting Kaestner on the
man with ball. Hank responded
by checking the ball loose and
kicking it far upfield, insuring
the Jay victory.
Scott now looks forward to the
Army game, here before a Big
Weekend crowd next Saturday.
The West Pointers have already
registered a 10-6 win over Rutgers and a 12-7 victory over
Princeton—the latter the same
score by which powerful Maryland defeated the Tigers.
